awd_titl_txt: Innovations in Statistical Methodology for Complex Surveys
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will modernize survey sampling tools for inference from survey data that can be used for complex problems such as survey integration or small area estimation. Increasingly, data sources have characteristics that traditional sampling tools are not readily designed to handle. The project will address important inference problems, such as model selection and hypothesis testing, based on data from complex samples and will extend the methods from parametric models to more flexible nonparametric models, such as quantile regression. The new methodology will have broad applicability to surveys in diverse disciplines, including agriculture, health, and demographics. Products of this research will include resources to equip practicing survey statisticians with tools to better meet the demands of policy makers and the public. Software and metadata produced by this project will be made publicly available. Graduate students will receive education and training, with an emphasis on the relationships between design-based and model-based inference.

This research project will develop innovative methods that will enable survey statisticians to exploit modern data structures and models in a statistically defensible way. The project will focus on three areas: (1) the use of inverse sampling and reweighting to obtain valid inferences from nonprobability samples, (2) methods for prediction and analytic inference under complex sample designs, and (3) hierarchical modeling strategies that are feasible to implement with large, diverse data sources. Methods to obtain approximately unbiased inferences from non-probability samples are highly relevant because of increases in nonresponse and use of non-survey data, such as administrative sources and satellite information. This examination of inference under complex sample designs will further research on hypothesis testing and the use of semiparametric models, particularly for situations in which the sample design is informative for the specified model. The investigators will further develop a hierarchical modeling approach that aggregates estimates obtained for sub-divisions of a large data source. The investigators have vetted this procedure using non-survey data and will apply the approach in a large-scale survey context.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have addressed several important practical problems in dealing with complex survey data.The findings can be summarized as follows: 

1. How to improve the representativeness of nonprobability samples using an independent probility sample is an emergiing research area. We have developed several methods for handling this problem and the findings are publised in several papers. 

 

2. Statistical inference with complex sampling has been addressed in this project. Bootstrap-based approach and an approximate Bayesian approaches are developed. In addition, empirical likelihood approach is developed for multi-source inference problems. Bayesian approach is also applied to developing multiple imputation incorporating model averaging. 

 

3.  Modern nonparametric function estimation techniques are aplied to developing robust approach to imputation for handling missing data. Specificall, we considered the Kernel ridge regression under reproduicing kernel Hilbert space and developed procedures for statistical inference. Also, small area estimation methods are developed for unit level model under informative sampling design.

 

4. Many of the small area estimation methods that we develop meet specific needs of the National Resources Inventory (NRI) and the Conservation Effects Assessment Project (CEAP), two surveys of natural resources and agriculture.  These surveys collect several measures of different types of erosion and land use. Small area estimates can improve the efficiency of resource allocation for conservation efforts.

We address a myriad of challenges that arise in small area estimation for the NRI and CEAP surveys. Sub-state small area estimates for NRI land use classifications should preserve the published state-level estimate. Concomitantly, estimation for land use classifications requires nonlinear models. As a result, existing benchmarking procedures in the literature are not immediately applicable. Berg and Fuller (2018) develops benchmarking procedures for nonlinear area level models and applies the methodology to benchmark county-level land use estimates to the published state-level estimate. Berg and Fuller (2018) focus on a single land use category. Wang et al. (2018) use a Bayesian hierarchical model to address the multi-faceted problem of small area estimation for multiple land use categories.   Berg and Kim (2020) develop an approximate best predictive procedure for small area estimation under informative sampling. We apply the method to construct sub-state estimates of mean sheet and rill erosion.  In CEAP, population quantiles are of interest and specification of a single parametric form for the wide variety of erosion variables is difficult. Berg and Lee (2019a,b) develop a small area estimation procedure based on a mixed effects quantile regression model. The procedure unifies the analysis of multiple response variables and ties the model to the parameter of interest. Measures of sheet and rill erosion in CEAP are skewed and contaminated with zeros. Berg et al. (2020) develop a zero-inflated lognormal model for small area estimation of sheet and rill erosion. We integrate satellite-derived land-cover classifications with administrative data on soil properties as auxiliary information.  Sun, Berg, and Zhu (2021) develop small area estimation procedures for a bivariate variable with binary and Gaussian components. We apply the method to data from CEAP.

The small area estimation methods that we develop have applicability beyond the NRI and CEAP studies. The benchmarking procedures for nonlinear models that we develop in Berg and Fuller (2018) are general and broadly applicable. The model of Wang et al. (2018) applies to spatially structured categorical data. The use of the generalized Dirichlet distribution permits the model to capture the design-variances of the survey-based estimators, without a normal approximation for the response distribution. The small area procedure for informative sampling that we develop in Berg and Kim (2021) has applicability to any sample that is selected with unequal probabilities.    Many agricultural and business surveys collect skewed response variables that are contaminated with zeros. The zero-inflated lognormal model of Berg, Lyu, and Hofmann (2020) is applicable to any variable that is skewed right and has a nontrivial proportion of observed zeros. Our research on small area estimation under a quantile regression model (Berg and Lee, 2019a,b) does not require full distributional assumptions. The bivariate small area model proposed in Sun, Berg, and Zhu (2021) is applicable to any survey that collects binary and continuous data.  

 

5. Developing Bayesian inference under informative sampling is challenging because there is no intrinsic likelihood function in the informative sampling. Wang, Kim, and Yang (2018) developed a so-called approximate Bayesian approach using the asymptotic normality of the pseudo maximum likelihood estimator of the model parameters. Sugasawa and Kim (2020) applied the approximate Bayesian method to handle regression estimation with many covariates. The idea is also applied to propensity score estimation problem in Sang and Kim (2020).
